verses.text: The main point of what we are saying is this: We have such a high priest, who is seated at the right hand of the throne of the Majesty in heaven,
verses.comment: The high priest seated at God's right hand speaks to the completed work and ongoing intercession of Christ. The Old Testament reference in Psalm 110:1 underlines the Messiah’s royal and priestly authority.

verses.text: a minister in the sanctuary and in the true tabernacle, which the Lord built, not man.
verses.comment: The contrast drawn here is between earthly worship spaces and the heavenly reality they point to. Christ ministers in the real and eternal sanctuary, not a copy made by human hands.

verses.text: For every high priest is appointed to offer gifts and sacrifices; thus it is necessary for this one also to have something to offer.
verses.comment: Jesus, as high priest, offers the perfect sacrifice—himself (see Hebrews 9:14)—fulfilling and surpassing Old Testament priesthood. The continual need for sacrifice is now satisfied in him.

verses.text: Now if he were on earth, he would not be a priest at all, since there are already those who offer the gifts according to the law.
verses.comment: Jesus does not serve as a Levitical priest but as the true priest in the heavenly temple, fulfilling and surpassing earthly ordinances. His priesthood is of a higher, eternal order.

verses.text: They serve a copy and shadow of the heavenly things. For when Moses was about to erect the tabernacle, he was warned, 'See that you make everything according to the pattern shown you on the mountain.'
verses.comment: Earthly worship and temple service foreshadow the heavenly reality. The emphasis on divine instruction and pattern points to the importance of liturgy and worship established by God.

verses.text: But as it is, he has obtained a more excellent ministry, inasmuch as he is the mediator of a better covenant, which is established on better promises.
verses.comment: Christ’s ministry is superior, establishing a new covenant that fulfills what the first merely foreshadowed. He mediates the definitive relationship between God and humanity.

verses.text: For if that first covenant had been faultless, there would have been no occasion for a second.
verses.comment: The necessity for a new covenant reveals that the old was provisional, preparing for a fuller, better relationship with God through Christ.

verses.text: For he finds fault with them when he says: 'Behold, the days are coming, declares the Lord, when I will establish a new covenant with the house of Israel and with the house of Judah.'
verses.comment: Direct quotation of Jeremiah 31:31 announces God's plan for a new, perfected covenant, extending God’s promise to all his people.

verses.text: 'Not like the covenant that I made with their fathers on the day when I took them by the hand to bring them out of the land of Egypt; for they did not continue in my covenant, and so I turned away from them, says the Lord.'
verses.comment: While the first covenant was established with Israel after the Exodus, it was broken by the people. The new covenant will not depend on human faithfulness but on God’s faithfulness.

verses.text: 'For this is the covenant that I will make with the house of Israel after those days, says the Lord: I will put my laws into their minds and write them on their hearts. And I will be their God, and they shall be my people.'
verses.comment: God’s promise points to inner transformation, not just external observance. This transformation is by the Spirit, forming a united people bound to God intimately—a profound image of the visible and spiritual Church.

verses.text: 'And they shall not teach, each one his neighbor and each one his brother, saying, "Know the Lord," for all shall know me, from the least of them to the greatest.'
verses.comment: This universal knowledge of God foreshadows the fullness of faith and truth accessible to all believers in unity, prefigured even in Christ’s teaching.

verses.text: 'For I will be merciful toward their iniquities, and I will remember their sins no more.'
verses.comment: God’s forgiveness is total and decisive, fulfilled in Christ’s atoning work. This mercy is perpetuated through the ministry of reconciliation and sacraments, ensuring constant access to God’s grace.

verses.text: In speaking of a new covenant, he makes the first one obsolete. And what is becoming obsolete and aging is ready to vanish away.
verses.comment: The first covenant was always pointing forward to Christ, who brings the fullness of what God had prepared through history, thus establishing a new foundation for the one apostolic faith.
